TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She was represented before the ORG by Mr I. Gažík , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by their Agent , Mr. PERSON , succeeded by PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant gave birth to a boy . A blood test showed that the applicant ’s husband had not fathered the child . The child ’s father is unknown .

As the applicant had health problems at the time of delivery , the child was placed in a social institution , with the applicant ’s consent , on DATE . The applicant visited her son regularly and bought necessary items and presents for him .
On DATE the applicant claimed that she should be allowed to take care of the child .

On DATE the Bratislava III ORG dismissed the action . The decision stated that the applicant ’s situation did not allow her to take appropriate care of her son , and that she suffered from a lasting mental disease . It was served on the applicant on DATE . The applicant did not appeal .
DATE and DATE the applicant was treated as an in - patient in a psychiatric hospital .
The Government contend , with reference to a list of the visits , that the applicant ’s last visit of her son took place on DATE .

The applicant submits that DATE and DATE she attempted to visit her son but was told that he was in the theatre . After her in - patient treatment had ended in DATE , the applicant submits , without giving further details , to have again unsuccessfully attempted to visit the child .

On DATE the Bratislava III ORG delivered a judgment depriving the applicant of her legal capacity on the ground that she suffered from a mental illness . On CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the first instance judgment and the decision became final on DATE .

The documents submitted by the Government indicate that ORG , on DATE , allowed the applicant ’s son to be adopted by a couple . The judgment became final on DATE . It stated , inter alia , that the applicant ’s last visit of her son took place on DATE . As she had failed to manifest any interest in the child thereafter , the boy had become free for adoption as from DATE . On DATE he had been placed in the pre - adoption care of the couple concerned . A guardian appointed to represent the interests of the child in the proceedings agreed to the adoption . It is apparent from the judgment that the applicant was not considered to be a party to the proceedings .

On DATE the Bratislava III ORG restored legal capacity to the applicant . Reference was made to an expert opinion submitted on CARDINAL DATE . In the opinion the expert summed up the applicant ’s situation , as described by the applicant during the examination . According to the opinion , the applicant stated that her child born in DATE had been placed in an institution . She could not visit him as she had been treated in a hospital . The boy had been adopted by other persons and the applicant had no information about him . She could only hope that the child was doing well . The applicant also stated that she had not been aware that it would have sufficed , as demonstrating her interest in the child , to send him a postcard .
On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer requested , on the applicant ’s behalf , that the applicant should be allowed to meet her son .

In a letter dated DATE and delivered on DATE the social institution where the child had been placed prior to his adoption replied that the boy had not been in its care as from DATE and that he had been adopted by a family . The adoption had been approved by a court and it was irrevocable . Reference was made to Section CARDINAL ) and , in substance , to Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .

The letter further stated that the applicant had visited the boy for the last time on DATE and that his father was unknown . The boy had been adopted under Section CARDINAL ) of LAW without the applicant ’s consent as she had failed to show interest in him for DATE .
The following relevant provisions of LAW ( PERSON o rodine ) were in force at the relevant time .

Under Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , following a person ’s adoption the same relations as those existing between parents and children come into being between the adopted person and the persons who adopted him or her .
Paragraph CARDINAL of LAW provides that a court decides on a person ’s adoption upon the proposal of those who wish to adopt that person .

Section CARDINAL ) , as in force until DATE , provided that , in cases where the legal representatives of a child to be adopted were his or her parents , their consent to the child ’s adoption was not required when they had failed to demonstrate , for DATE , real interest in the child which they normally should show as parents . With effect from DATE this provision was extended in that it enumerated the following reasons as examples of the GPE failure to show real interest in the child : failure to visit the child regularly , failure to comply regularly and voluntarily with the obligation to provide for the child ’s maintenance , failure to show willingness to adjust , as far as possible , their family and social situation in a manner permitting them to take personal care of the child unless they were prevented from doing so for a serious reason .

Pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL of Section CARDINAL , in such cases it is required that a guardian appointed to represent the interests of the child in the context of the adoption proceedings should give his or her consent to the child ’s adoption .
Under LAW ) , prior to a judicial decision on his or her adoption , the child concerned has to be in care of the person wishing to adopt him or her for DATE .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that , following a person ’s adoption , mutual rights and obligations existing between that person and his or her original family cease to exist . The rights and obligations of a guardian appointed , as the case may be , to exercise such parental rights also cease to exist following the adoption of the person concerned .

Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that parties to proceedings concerning the adoption of a minor are the child to be adopted , his or her parents , the person adopting the child and his or her spouse .

Under paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL , the parents of the child to be adopted are not parties to proceedings when they are deprived of parental rights or of their legal capacity as well as in cases where their agreement is not required for adoption of their child notwithstanding that they are his or her legal representatives .
